item.title: Alcohol as a social technology to check the trustworthiness of others
item.description: Ohhh, never thought of this hypothesis: that the act of getting drunk together might be a social technology that helps us verify the trustworthiness of others by inhibiting their higher cognitive functions and thus making it harder to consciously fake things. That would make sense.

item.title: SQLite and EF Core Concurrency Tokens
item.description: Entity Framework Core has great built-in support for optimistic concurrency control. The best way to utilize this on SQL Server is via a rowversion column. Unfortunately, SQLite has no such feature. This post show how to implement similar functionality using a trigger.

item.title: 6- Axis IMU with ESP32
item.description: 6- Axis IMU based on ESP32 for gaming/learning, and quadcopter. basically, i want to make a easy-to-create quadcopter with ESP WIFI, or BLE conection, a platform that i can freely add some other sensors/camera on it ... so i make this board in advance to test the IMU, based on MPU6050. There MOSFET drivers for motors on the board, but i have not tested it yet with motors. by now, the IMU output seems good ..
item.author: (Makerfabs)

item.description: What. A. Week. I've been absolutely non-stop publishing data breaches to HIBP whilst simultaneously putting in place the framework to start advising NordVPN on their cybers and open sourcing the HIBP code base at the same time (and a bunch of other more boring stuff that didn't make the cut)
item.author: (Troy Hunt's Picture)

item.title: Automate everything that is not part of the problem you’re solving
item.description: When faced with the decision if something is worth automating or not, the default reaction for most developers and product managers will be simple: estimating the time spent on a manual task, and comparing it with the time it would take to automate the task away. Whatever takes the least time wins. When building Offen, the decision of what to automate came up quite a few times as well, and I have realized that only looking at time spent might be a bit short-sighted.
item.author: (Frederik Ring)
